ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A very good introduction and survey of the ideas of geometric rep theory (GRT). I learned a lot about techniques that I had seen before in rep theory, but didn't appreciate. Goes through primarily chapter 3 of Chriss and Ginzburg's book "Representation Theory and Complex Geometry". Its a great way to see how algebraic geometry and algebraic topology meet with rep theory to produce some really interesting ideas.

I learned a good deal about the connections between representation theory and algebraic geometry especially the roles that flag varieties and cohomology rings play. I also got better and learning how to read textbooks and prep lectures.
I learned more in this class than any other class I've ever taken.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I just hope something like this is given again. There's certainly demand for it among the undergrads.

The course did a very good job of presenting the material from Chriss and Ginzburg. Most of the lectures were good and easy enough to follow. Some people weren't as prepared to lecture as others but on a whole it was good.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, especially to those interested in geometry and mathematical physics. It really helps to have a good background in algebraic topology, and some algebraic geometry ahead of time.

I would recommend this course. The material was interesting though how well it's taught depends on who's giving the lecture. Algebraic geometry at the level of chapters 2 & 3 of Hartshorne is needed at points, but otherwise it's nothing too intense.
